1 Basics for success
The following factors make a good scientific paper: Clear problemobjective
Logical, structured structure
Clean use of terms, plausibility
Comprehensible structure of thought (through clean structure, argumentation, references, objectivity, etc.)
Accuracy in terms of content and form
Systematic approach and critical questioning of the results
Interesting presentation of facts (e.g. also through successful illustrations, etc.)

parties. The study must be useful to others. The study must say things about this subject that have not yet been said, or it must view things that have already been said from a new perspective. the study must contain information that
makes it possible to verify whether its hypotheses are false or true. It must therefore contain information that makes it
possible to continue the debate in the scientific community. try to view the work objectively. 2 Formalities
2.1 Components of the student thesis
Please use the templates, especially to have the title page, the declaration of
independence and all directories automatically generated. The thesis is to be written
according to the following structure: Title page with the following contents: see specification
Assignment: Copy the text of the assignment unchanged and in its entirety
Declaration of independence

2.2 Structure of the thesis
The IMRAD (Introduction, Methods, Results and Discussion) scheme is a common
standard. Proposal for structuring: Chapter 1 Introduction Motivate the problem in the application context, describe the
task in your own words and give an overview of the work. Chapter 2 Basics Presentation of mathematical, technical, algorithmic or other basic
knowledge in order to understand the work. Chapter 3 Related Works To show who has already dealt with the topic or similar
related topics, which solutions have been described and what the connection of the
respective to one's own work is. Chapter 4 (or more) Methods and Implementation Main part of the thesis: first
describe the concept, then the realization. Chapter 5 Results Presenting the results objectively and describing how exactly the
results were collected. Draw attention to special features. Chapter 6 Discussion Discuss the implemented solution based on the results.

3.1 Font
Continuous text in serif font creates good readability. Headlines can look nice in sans
serif bold. Font sizes to use: Body text: 11 pt
Headings (h1-h2-h3): 18 pt; 14 pt; 12 pt
Do not choose line spacing too large: 1.2 times is advisable. Font markup
Emphasis can be realized by italics, bold, capitals, small caps and the font family. But
don't use several AT ONCE! Underlining is taboo, bold font and capital letters should be
used as sparingly as possible! For source code, a monospace font is recommended (e.g. Courier New). Free variables
and free function names should be set in italics, but signs with a fixed meaning should
not. The latter are well-known functions (e.g. sincos, lim), constants (e.g. Euler's
number e, the circle number π or your own chosen constant symbols) or unit symbols
(e.g. ms, kHz). Mathematical variable names never consist of multiple letters! If more
characters are needed for clarification, they can appear in the subscript (also not
italicized). Examples of font markup in formulas: False: func(x)  πxmaxsin(2x)

3.2 Page layout
The page numbers begin on the right (odd) side with the introduction. Chapter
beginnings are always on a right (odd) page. If necessary, the previous (left) page
remains empty. 3.3 Recurring Elements
Figures
are according to the scheme Fig.Chapter No..lfd.Nr.:title. These are
signatures. Find a meaningful title. The illustration must be self-explanatory along with
its title. Pay attention to high quality, prefer vector graphics. Furthermore, make sure that
the individual parts of the image are sufficiently large and that the captions are
sufficiently large for easy readability. Tables
are according to the schedule of Table Chapter No..lfd.Nr.:title. These are
headings. As with illustrations, a meaningful title is important. Source code
are according to the scheme ListingChapter No..lfd.Nr.:title,filename. Signatures can be used for short code passages, otherwise headings. Footnotes
for annotations or translations. If the footnote refers to a word, the footnote mark is
immediately after it. If it refers to a sentence, it is immediately after the sentence period. Be sparing with footnotes. Think about how the content can possibly be sensibly
accommodated in the text. 4 Quotes

4.3 Technique of citation
Word-for-word (direct) quotation Useful for definition and statements that could not be
described more accurately. Is in quotation marks if it is no longer than 4 lines. Otherwise, it is marked with an indentation of the entire quotation block (then without quotation
marks). Directly after the quote is the source in the running text (Harvard method). Word-
for-word quotations must be taken honestly and verbatim, no reformulations or
abbreviations that distort the meaning may be made. Text highlighting or errors in the
original text must also be taken over (these can be marked with a [sic]. Latin for "so" or
"really so"). Double quotation marks are replaced by single quotation marks in the quote. Omissions must be marked with [.] (be careful not to distort the meaning of the original). Adaptations of the original, e.g. to the grammatical case of one's own work, should be
written directly in square brackets to the relevant passage as well as when inserting words
or highlighting them (write a clear comment in the square brackets, e.g. [emphasis
added]). Word-for-word quotes should be used sparingly! Analogous (indirect) quotation Here, the content of sentences or paragraphs from the
original literature is reproduced in the same way. The strict rules of verbatim quotation do
not apply, but here too no thoughts may be falsified, omitted or added. In the
sentenceparagraph that includes the thought content of the external source, there must

not apply, but here too no thoughts may be falsified, omitted or added. In the
sentenceparagraph that includes the thought content of the external source, there must
be a "sound", "according to" or similar. In the case of an analogous quotation, the citation
bracket is placed before the sentence period if it only goes over one sentence. If the
quotation is several sentences long, the citation bracket is placed after the sentence
point of the last sentence of the quotation. Images from external sources must be reproduced unchanged or the changes must be
clearly identified. The source reference belongs at the end of the caption (in square
brackets). If a third-party illustration was used as a template for a separate figure, an
indication is also required, e.g. "according to [XY01, Fig. X.Y2]". "Second-hand" quotes are those in which a source is cited, the content of which is a
quotation on the actual material. Such quotes are to be avoided! An exception is the
unavailability of the original source, but this rarely happens. A second-hand citation must
be marked with the note "cited by", e.g. "[MXY01] cited after [XY01]" (in this case, [MXY01] would be the original source and [XY01] would be the cited source). Both works
must be listed in the bibliography. Good style
is to mention the authors of an external source by name - if there are more than two
authors, use the form "SurnameofFirst Author et al." - but it is also possible to use the
citation clip directly for this. Examples: Direct quote:

Valuable sources should be used, e.g. papers from reputable conferences with review
systems or those that have already been cited frequently. Printed sources tend to be
more reputable and should be preferred to web sources such as forums, tutorials or
Wikipedia. Wikipedia can be a first point of contact, but it is scientifically controversial. It is better to look for "real" literature from there. Basic problems: Usually only one paper is given by supervisors
you yourself lack an overview of the subject area
Theres a lot of literature out there, and a lot of it is bad
there is no time for an exhaustive search
Strategy: Read the given paper in its entirety (sometimes several times), write down
important technical terms (buzzwords)
Read related work again, develop a feel for the subject area
examine related works: usually it is enough to read the abstract and the
resultsdiscussion to get an impression
Literature divides: relevant recent papers, review articles (STARs) as source
resources, older papers (good candidates for reverse searches)
These means (STARs, old papers, buzzwords, names of major conferences) are the basis
for further research. Where should you look? 5.1 Search engines (selection)

5.2 Techniques
Find new works through older ones Search for the older publication. Then display the
papers that cite the older work -- this option is usually called "Referenced by" "Cited
by". Then search for the displayed (new) work. Find new work through buzzwords Enter buzzwords in search engine. Sort by
publication date and number of citations. Skimming the first hits (new buzzwords may
open up). Possibly search for research groups that are known in the specific problem
area and comb through their publication lists. New work through conferences After you have found relevant research fields and
keywords, you can search for major conferences in these fields. Look through the
publication lists there and then do more research. New works by well-known authors Search for publication lists of authors who are
frequently mentioned in the relevant subject area or whose names appear frequently in
the bibliography. Note the order in which the author is named in the header of a paper. The first author is the author of (most of) the work. On the far right, the head of the
departmentinstitutechair is typically the supervisor of the thesis. 5.3 Reading a Source I (Papers)
Start with the abstract and resultsdiscussion section to quickly get to the essential

these terms interesting for your task? Can you expand your search queries with

contain highly condensed information. Typically, they need to be read multiple times to

SQ3R method: survey, question, read, repeat, review
Survey: Get an overview, study the table of contents: What was covered? How is
the text divided? What is the basis on which the author relies? What is important
to you? Question: Formulating questions for the text: what do you expect this text to
provide information about for your own work? Read: Read the chapters relevant to your question
Repeat: It's not a bad thing if you haven't completely understood everything
when you read a chapter for the first time. Just repeat what you understood
(preferably out loud). If you are stuck: Just read and repeat what you have
understood (preferably out loud). If you are stuck: Just read and repeat what you

the text been answered? Do new questions arise? 5.5 Evaluating a Source

without reference to the source should not be used. 6 Style
Always use scientific language: never slang! Terms
Use technical terms, but not to obfuscate content. The reader must understand them. If
you are unsure, create a glossary. Use German instead of English terms if they exist (e.g. "Datei" instead of "File" or "Update" instead of "Update"). If there is a technical term for a
thing, use it instead of a synonym. Filler phrases
Avoid standard clauses such as "How easy to see.". Do not intersperse relativizations
("many", "often", "mostly"), exaggerations ("enormous", "unbelievable"), filler words ("yes", "well"), reassurance words ("to a certain extent", "somehow", "well"), argumentation
substitute words ("natural", "self-evident") or personal opinions. Own statements are not
prohibited in principle, but must be critically reflected on and justified. Remain modest in
your explanations, do not use arrogant formulations (negative example: "The basis is
trivially provided by the well-known theories from tensor arithmetic"). Avoid wording with
"you", "we" or "I". Intelligibility
Do not write in an artificially complicated way, but in the same way as you would explain

metadata.context: Bad: It is a well-known problem in computer graphics that this interface limits the

chunks.content:
"you", "we" or "I". Intelligibility
Do not write in an artificially complicated way, but in the same way as you would explain
a scientific fact orally to a professor. Write short, clear sentences that eliminate ambiguity
and are meaningful in terms of content. Terms must be clearly defined and consistency
must be ensured when using them. Aim for an even linguistic level, stay logical and never
lose the thread. Stay problem-focused. Write for the reader! Rules of thumb for
comprehensibility: Each sentence contains a statement
Each paragraph contains a thought
Each section contains a group of thoughts
Examples: Bad: It is a well-known problem in computer graphics that this interface limits the

possibilities, which is why some data, such as e.g. Textures are not stored in the
conventional main memory, but are transferred once to the graphics card and stored
there in the graphics memory. Better: The fact that this interface limits the possibilities is a well-known problem in
computer graphics. Therefore, it is common to store data such as textures in graphics
memory instead of conventional main memory. This means that they only have to be
transferred to the graphics card once. Syntax
Use subordinate clauses sparingly: beware of box and stair sentences! Observe a clear
distribution of roles: main information in the main clause, secondary information in the
subordinate clause. Simply delete subordinate clauses without (relevant) content. Avoid
genitive chains. Use verbs instead of noun-auxiliary verb constructs ("hint" instead of
"hint", "depends" instead of "is dependent"). Whenever there is a choice between a verb
and something else: Take a verb! Do not use prepositional nesting, i.e. no more than one
preposition ("in, below, above, between, before, after, against.") per sentence (negative
example: "There is a connection between spaces defined above this metric"). Write in a
positive sense instead of a negative one: don't use double negatives and write what is and
not what is not. Furthermore, avoid too many passive formulations, but write them in an
active style. Abbreviations
Use abbreviations sparingly and always use them clearly. Explain them at the first

Use abbreviations sparingly and always use them clearly. Explain them at the first
occurrence and write a list of abbreviations. Generally known abbreviations (according to
the Duden) do not need to be included in it. Don't rely on a reader to be able to remember

many pages after their first introduction, explain them again by means of a short
repetition. For example, write "Here again the value α, i.e. the angle of rotation, is used
to.", even though you introduced the variable α 3 chapters ago. Structure
Avoid bullet point lists, but rather write in prose form. Avoid the frequent use of forward or
backward references (e.g. "As will be seen in Chapter X." or "As shown in Chapter Y."). Pictures
Use illustrations, tables, and diagrams to make complex textual statements more
understandable ("tangible"), but avoid mapping trivialities. All figures or tables must be
self-explanatory (axis labels, legends, color meaning, units, etc.). The use of an
illustration does not make a textual description superfluous: a) the continuous text must
also function without an illustration and b) the illustration must not replace the
continuous text. Do not write any significant new information solely in the figure (negative

Numbers
The numbers "zero" to "twelve" are usually written out in continuous text, unless there is
a special emphasis on numerical size. Units are generally abbreviated without a dot (kg, km, h, min.). Between the value and the unit symbol there is a narrow non-breaking
space (so never wrap the line here). Avoid the sequential spelling of non-meaningful
numbers (negative example: "256 64-bit registers."). Formulas
A consistent style should be used and a uniform naming convention should be
established for variables, function names, etc. Don't use overloaded symbolism, but still
remain exact. If possible, avoid formulas in the running text. They disturb the flow of
reading and sometimes sabotage the text layout. Use separate formula environments
instead. GNP.: The Pythagorean theorem is a fundamental theorem of (Euclidean) geometry and reads: a2  b2  c2
The equation holds for any right triangle if a and b are its cathetes and c is its
hypotenuse. Do not write unnecessarily complicated and long derivations in the body. Reduce to the
essentials (the rest in the appendix if necessary). Source code
Never put complete parts of the source code in the main text! If at all, then only selected
excerpts due to special circumstances. Instead, explain the developed procedures using
structure and flow diagrams or pseudocode. Units

7 Best Practice
Below you can read tips for the chapters presented according to the IMRAD
(Introduction, Methods, Results and Discussion) scheme. Introduction
TABLES: 0,1  0,1  0,1  0,1 V  0,1  0,1  0,1  0,1
0,2  0,2  0,2  0,2 V  0,2  0,2  0,2  0,2........

At the very beginning of the written elaboration, the introduction should provide a handy
motivation for the task and elegantly introduce the topic. Here, the problem is presented
in the context of an application and the content of the thesis is briefly anticipated. What
problem has been solved, why is it relevant? What is the procedure? What was
thematically limited, what was excluded? It is important to work out your own
contribution in a few concise sentences. (The conclusion should refer to these
contributions at the end in order to give the work a narrative bracket.) The introduction
ends with an overview of the work. The contents of the individual chapters are briefly
described (avoid trivial statements such as "The results are presented in the results
chapter 7."). Tip: Avoid standard intros such as "XY is an important field of application in
computer graphics" or "XY has become indispensable in computer graphics". Related works
The aim is to show who has already dealt with the topic or similar related topics, which
solutions have been described and what the connection of the respective work to one's
own is. Consider the "4 Ws" as a reminder: What problem was addressed? How was the
problem solved? What did it achieve? How does it relate to your own work? In this
chapter, it is particularly difficult to create a common thread and prevent the text from
degenerating into a paper listing. There are strategies that can also be combined: chronologically or aspect-oriented. In the chronological listing, related works are
described in chronological order, thus giving a historical outline of the approaches to

chunks.content:
chronologically or aspect-oriented. In the chronological listing, related works are
described in chronological order, thus giving a historical outline of the approaches to
solving the problem under consideration. Typically, the first source in time is described
more precisely, as well as the sources that follow closer in time. Then you can jump a bit
and concentrate on milestones. Finally, the current status should be looked at more
closely. The second strategy, aspect-oriented citation, provides for a division of the
papers into aspects of one's own problem. For example, if it is about volume rendering
with global lighting, papers on volume rendering in general, then sources on advanced
methods, and finally papers on the integration of global lighting should be presented one
after the other (possibly even in separate sections). Basics
Here, mathematical, technical, algorithmic and other knowledge is to be explained, but
only as much as is needed to understand the work. The own level of knowledge before
starting the thesis can be regarded as known prior knowledge. Move further basic
knowledge or detailed mathematical derivations to the appendix. The work is not a
textbook. Explanations of the technical terms used may be provided here (or at the
beginning of the methodology chapter). Methodology and implementation
Here, one's own work is first described conceptually, including problem analysis and the
search for and finding solutions. At this point, a theoretical examination of the material
should take place. Do not explain on the basis of concrete APIs or source code

metadata.context: should take place. Do not explain on the basis of concrete APIs or source code

chunks.content:
(pseudocode, on the other hand, is allowed). Only then does the description of the
implementation follow. In most cases the implementation as software. Make sure you
have a clear and problem-related selection of code examples or (sub-)class diagrams. Detailed and comprehensive descriptions should be included in the appendix, if at all
necessary. Results
Here is an objective presentation of the results. A division into quantitative evaluation
(generation of measurement data) and qualitative evaluation (surveysexpert
feedbackdescription of special features) makes sense. For each evaluated fact, the
result should first be shown (e.g. as a figure or table), then it is described and only then
interpreted. An evaluation has not yet taken place. Discussion
Only in the discussion part can the results be critically questioned and assessed. Based
on this, the pros and cons (of the developed method) are worked out. Summary
The thesis is briefly summarized and evaluated; the resultssolutions are condensed into
a conclusion (here the arc is drawn to the problems raised in the introduction). An
assessment of the general usefulness of the developed methods can be given. Tip: End
with something positive! In the conclusion, show the "good" things first, then the "bad". For the latter, you note that they are solvable and that the developed methods are
nevertheless promising. View
Finally, the outlook shows useful extensions of the developed methods or possibilities for
further research. The current vulnerabilities should be explained as opportunities for new
concepts. General

when you are in a "tired" phase (instead do simple tasks: organizing literature, doing the
household or relaxing.). Think about daily physical exercise. This also promotes mental
performance. 9 Tips for Practical ElaborationImplementation
Your supervisor will certainly be able to give you good advice so that you don't have to
develop your software "from scratch". Also explicitly discuss with your supervisor the
range of functions that your developed components should provide and complete these
tasks first. If you find out in the course of editing that you still have time for further
functionality, this will be appreciated and credited to you as a bonus. When it comes to your implementations, keep the KISS principle ("Keep it simple and
stupid" or "Keep it small and simple") in mind. Try to find the simplest implementation for
the given problem. In general, no mature software product is expected, a functional
prototype is quite sufficient. However, you should not be stingy with comments in the
source code and appropriate documentation. A good program structuresoftware design
is also essential. This helps all those who want to reuse their software later, e.g. for follow-
up theses, in teaching, etc. Maybe it's you who wants to use your own software again later
and is then happy that all functionalities are well structured and explained.

10 Procrastination Techniques (procrastination)
Many students invest too much time in implementation. Reasons for this are partly
"thoughts of perfection" or the desire to include even more program features in the
software. Unfortunately, there is also the problem that some prefer to deal intensively
with the implementation in order to avoid written work. Possibly because they don't know
exactly how to "start". Most likely, they just lack some experience in planning and
implementing such a large work. The phenomenon of procrastination is not unknown and is also referred to as student
syndrome. If you yourself are plagued by such thoughts or have the feeling that you are
unable or only idle to plan your activities, contact your supervisor in good time and work
out a concept for the division of work together. Be aware: You are certainly not the first
with writer's block and you can be helped! 11 Notes on the Presentations
11.1 Defense
Defense It is not a mere summary of the content that has emerged. Due to the limited
speaking time, students should show that they are able to select important content and
leave out unimportant content (or only mention it in passing). In particular, the company's
own contributions are to be highlighted. Try to prepare and present your knowledge as
understandably as possible. Unlike you, the audience does not know every detail of the
work and does not want to be informed about every little problem that has arisen during
the processing time. First, you should start with good motivation and present the task. Be
creative and arouse the interest of your audience! This also includes explicitly listing the

metadata.context: results from measurements or surveys are usually presented and discussed. The

chunks.content:
the processing time. First, you should start with good motivation and present the task. Be
creative and arouse the interest of your audience! This also includes explicitly listing the
challenges (i.e. why is your problem a problem at all). This can be done via a single slide
entitled "Challenges". This is followed by a short outline to give a roadmap through the
lecture. This is followed by related work and technical basics. These should be as concise
as possible. A defense is not a lecture! In addition, many things were already discussed in
the interim presentation. The core of the work, one's own performance, should be given
the largest part of the presentation time. In the case of particularly extensive work, it is
sometimes necessary to discuss only one part in detail and to present the remaining parts
in an overview. Always keep the common thread and think carefully about what
knowledge the listener needs and when to follow the lecture, so you avoid double
explanations. Depending on the type of work, it is helpful to start with a big picture before
explaining finer structures. In this way, you give the listener an orientation aid. At the end, results from measurements or surveys are usually presented and discussed. The

metadata.context: results from measurements or surveys are usually presented and discussed. The

chunks.content:
presentation concludes with a brief conclusion, in which you can once again highlight
your own performance and refer to the taskintroduction. You are welcome to make the
bow and show the challenge slide again. This time (20 minutes), in addition to each sub-
problem, you list a short summary of your presented solution(s). This is followed by a
demonstration of the developed application and the obligatory QA session. 11.2 QA session
See the QA session as an opportunity to present more in-depth knowledge. Some of the
questions are addressed in detail to you as an "expert", but some are of a simple nature
and more of an indication that parts of your presentation were not understood. In this
case, react confidently and calmly. Under no circumstances should you answer clumsily
or arrogantly. If you have difficulty understanding, the problem is often due to the
structure of the presentation (especially if many details are discussed but an overall
overview is missing). Don't see expert questions as a personal attack and try to answer
them as objectively as possible. This is not always easy, after all, you have been working
on the task for a long time and may have "grown together" with it. In this situation, try to
look at the work from a distance and do not justify yourself for your actions, especially if
your approach is questioned. Instead, allow alternative solutions and, for example, give a
comparative assessment of your own solution. 11.3 Miscellaneous
Time limit The given time limit is hard and should be adhered to at all costs. During your
presentation, the last 5 minutes of presentation time will be discreetly displayed. If you
are about to overstay, you will be informed verbally. Now you should definitely get the bow

chunks.content:
presentation, the last 5 minutes of presentation time will be discreetly displayed. If you
are about to overstay, you will be informed verbally. Now you should definitely get the bow
and conclude the presentation, otherwise there is a risk of deductions in the evaluation. Clothing Come to the lectures neatly dressed. However, you do not need to appear in a
suit. For the defense of theses, dark long trousers and a shirt or a simple sweater are
sufficient. T-shirts with prints or casual trousers make you appear rather untrustworthy as
a speaker. Appear Be as relaxed and confident as possible. Try not to appear too stiff (but also not
too hyper). Try to lead through the lecture in a targeted manner through speaking speed
and accentuation and to control the listener's attention. Practice Practice your presentation in advance e.g. in front of the mirror or in front of good
friends. In this way, you can already get initial feedback on comprehensibility. You will also
learn to assess whether the presentation fits into the time limit. Practicing the lecture is
also a very good way to train a relaxed posture and way of speaking. Slides Don't write everything you say on the slides. There is a great danger that it will then
look as if you are simply reading. Instead, create good illustrations and schemes. Slides
support the presentation much more in this way, because facts are often more
understandable and tangible graphically. Avoid unnecessary text in your presentation.

Backup slides If you had to take detailed knowledge out of the presentation slides due to
time constraints, don't be afraid to collect them as an attachment. In the QA session, the extra slides can help with your explanations and also show that you have a deep
understanding of the material. References in the slides Figures and descriptions of related works must be correctly
marked as citations, e.g. with the square citation brackets. Use the same abbreviations
here as in your written elaboration. Create a slide with the references used in the
presentation for the appendix, but do not show this slide in the presentation. Intermediate questions Generally agree to intermediate questions, but do not waste
valuable speaking time. Try to return to the presentation as quickly as possible and refer
to the QA session for questions that would take too long to answer. 12 Evaluation Criteria
